awd_titl_txt: CRII: CIF: Dynamic Network Event Detection with Time-Series Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Network data is ubiquitous in real-world applications, e.g., communication networks, social networks, computer networks, sensor networks, power grids, World Wide Web, and Internet of Things. In these applications, the collected data are usually associated with a network structure, and the network structure may correspond to communication links in wireless networks, information flows in social networks, and causal relationships between the network nodes. Compared to individual entities, network data, by their interconnected nature, contain rich causal and correlation information, and present both complication and opportunity for statistical inference. Timely detection of dynamic events as soon as they occur is a problem of great interest, especially as false alarms are possible in networks of really large sizes, and measurements taken from one part of the network may not accurately capture events in another part of the network. This project addresses this challenge and develops a comprehensive framework for dynamic event detection in networks with time-series data. The developed methodology in this project can benefit a wide range of applications, e.g., intrusion detection in computer networks, epidemic detection, seismic event detection, and fake news detection in social networks. This project will substantially advance the understanding of how to accurately model and sequentially detect an event with a dynamic nature, and how to exploit network topology for reliable and computationally efficient detection in networks. 

In the project, the following two thrusts will be explored: (i) detection of dynamics at a single node; and (ii) detection of dynamics in the network. Practical applications, e.g., fault detection in electric motor, dynamic community detection in social networks and seismic event detection, will be studied to validate algorithms developed in this project. Tools from probability theory, information theory and stochastic optimization will be used to develop novel methodologies that address the underlying challenges in this project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project is to develop a comprehensive framework for dynamic event detection in networks with time-series data. The main approach is to model the dynamically changing statistical behavior using a set of cascaded transient phases, where each phase is associated with a distinct data generating distribution. Several important challenges in this project include: data heterogeneity, unlabeled samples from sensor networks, dynamic anomaly, robustness, and data-driven approaches. The following are the major research findings from the project.

1. We investigated the problem of quickest moving anomaly detection in networks, where the anomaly moves across the network, and the node that it affects changes with time. We propose to use a discrete-time Markov chain to model the unknown trajectory of the moving anomaly, and design a windowed generalized likelihood ratio?based test. We theoretically prove that it is asymptotically optimal. We also studied other detection algorithms including the dynamic Shiryaev-Roberts test, a quickest change detection algorithm with recursive change point estimation, and a mixture cumulative sum (CUSUM) algorithm. We further developed the lower bound on the mean time to false alarm.

2. We studied the problem of quickest change detection (QCD) in anonymous heterogeneous sensor networks, where the samples received by the fusion center is unlabeled. We studied two different settings: 1) at some unknown time, an event changes the data-generating distribution of all the sensors and 2) at some unknown time, an anomaly changes the data-generating distribution of one node and the node changes with time. The goal is to detect the change as quickly as possible, subject to false alarm constraints. We designed a mixture CuSum algorithm and proved its optimality under Lorden's criterion. For large networks, we also designed a computationally efficient test, and theoretically analyzed its false alarm rate.

3. We investigated the problem of robust hypothesis testing, where under the null and the alternative hypotheses, the data-generating distributions are assumed to be in some uncertainty sets, and the goal is to design a test that performs well under the worst-case distributions over the uncertainty sets. We studied the data-driven setting, where the uncertainty sets are centered around empirical distributions of training samples from the null and alternative hypotheses, respectively; and are constrained via the kernel method. We developed robust tests with theoretical characterization of the worst-case probability of errors.

4. We investigated the problem of quickest change detection in Markov and hidden Markov models, and designed data-driven methods. Our method is based on the kernel approach, and it applies to general state space. The test can be updated recursively in a computationally efficient way. We theoretically characterized the performance bounds on the average running length and worst-case average detection delay. We also applied our approach to a practical problem of fault detection in power systems, and demonstrated the practical usefullness of our approach.


The results and findings of this project have been disseminated through numerous journal and conference publications as well as conference presentations in research communities of signal processing and information theory. In 2021, the PI also prepared and published a survey paper onIEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Information Theory focusing on the topic of quickest change detection in this project.

The students working on the project are trained with new mathematical techniques on the topics of quickest change detection, hypothesis testing, distributionally robust optimization. They also had opportunities to collaborate with other researchers from other discipline, e.g., power systems, and to present the research results at various conferences.
